comments.content:
You won't necessarily backup across the corporate VPN--in fact, that may expressly be forbidden to preserve bandwidth based on the type of VPN. It's reasonable to assume that backups will be created locally or on other company assets (workstations)--forcing encryption will prevent exfiltration from backups.
I think that remote wiping is important, but encrypting backups and forcing VPN connections would probably be higher priority.

discussion.content:
If VPN is always on, aren't all mobile backups already encrypted? 
If, while traveling, a device was lost, or stolen, wouldn't you want to "issue a remote wipe of corporate and personal partitions?"

Maybe: D: The company should install a temporary CCTV system to detect unauthorized access to physical offices?

If somebody has been slipping into offices, it is likely to be an insider.
Getting inside an office is not much use if the user is logged out. You would need to get into the office right after the user leaves, and while the user is still logged in (users often to fail to logout, or remove their CACs).

Most likely, what is happening is: an insider is watching office doors, when somebody leaves, the attacker slips inside that office while the user is still logged in. This would require an insider.

If a tester could social engineer his/her way into an office, that would tell you nothing, except that it could be done. But, even then, there is no reason to think that the tester is using the same method as the actual attacker.

comments.content: B would defeat the purpose of the underlining concern: "...concerned about unauthorized access to its physical offices". The consulting company should test this. Answer is correct.

discussion.content:
Maybe: B. The consultant should be granted access to all physical access control systems to review logs and evaluate the likelihood of the threat 
There is no reason to think that the offices were access by social engineering. Certainly accessing offices by social engineering would not cover "all aspects of corporate security." And what about the offices the consultant could not enter by social engineering? Would those offices go unchecked?
Seems to me, the first thing to do would be to look at the logs, and see who logged in, from where, and when.

discussion.content:
It is absolutely C
There is a mismatch between company policy and regulatory requirement. If the vendor says it's ok, and your local policy says it's ok, and the REGULATORY AGENCY FOR YOUR BUSINESS says it's not ok, guess what? Not ok.

I agree with the answer provided by Trap_D0_r but I also think the question is poorly constructed. The question includes "assessor is working with an organization to review the policies and procedures" then ask what is most appropriate to advise. The answer to segment the system would be a good short-term solution to the underlying security problem of shared hardware but that is not the question. comments.content: Data remnants is something Comptia brings up a lot so I can argue for that one (remember, it's comptia not real life). in the real word the security folks would be concerned with how the migration happens - the CIA of the data. I have no idea why storage encryption would be an answer though other than maybe after the fact.

discussion.content:
How about: "none of the above" ?

A. Data remnants
Possibe that small amounts of data could be left over after transferring data. Also possible that such data remnants could be sensitive. I suppose that could be a concern for the CISO. Although it seems to me that such remnants would be easy enough to dispose of.

B. Sovereignty
Data Sovereignty is the concept that information that has been converted and stored in binary digital form is subject to the laws of the country in which it is located. I see no reason that would be relevant here.

C. Compatible services
There will only be one service, so that will not be an issue.

D. Storage encryption
That is the sort of thing a CISO would be concerned with, but I don't see any reason to think that would be a special issue here.

E. Data migration
This could be difficult, but no reason to think it's a special *security* concern.

F. Chain of custody
This deals with forensic evidence of a crime. Not relevant here.
